WRITING.TEXT: How did you cook the Salmon?
Gladly, except my wife probably ate the leftovers already.

WRITING.TITLE: [Homemade] Soft Shell Crabs with Black Bean Corn Relish, Spicy Roasted Butternut Squash, Kale Salad
[Homemade] Gai Pad Krapow (Thai Holy Basil Chicken)

WRITING.TEXT: That's my go to Thai dish, when cooking and dining out. Yours looks good. Did you use Thai or Holy Basil? Recipe?

I usually just eyeball it on Strats/Teles, it really has come from years of trial and error. That's the fun thing about bolt-on guitars, unless you wrench the screws too much, you really can't hurt them. I've taken necks off, shimmed them, taken neck off, re-shim, etc. till it's right.
One tip, instead of restringing every time, I take a Capo or Gaff tape an place on the first fret to hold the strings on (after slacking them of course).

I'm more of a technician than a player, but I found the best way to get better is to play in a band. That could be just jamming with friends or actually playing shows. Playing with others (even those better than you) will up your game.
Also, if just starting out I think a lot of bands rehearse too much trying to make it perfect before playing a show. I say learn the songs to the best of your ability then play a show, might not be the best, but it will get better.

For electronics parts mouser.com, cedist.com, and mojotone.com or sometimes I just Google the best price.
For making cables usually toursupply.com

I don't really want to go into calling out brands I don't like, but I prefer either Switchcraft, G H, or Neutrik connectors when soldering and George L's and now my own 3 Monkeys Solderless connectors for solderless.
In particular, I prefer the Neutrik SilentPlug over the Switchcraft 1/4"Silent plug, because it works with acoustics better than the Switchcraft.
For cable I like Mogami or Canare for soldered cables.
I rarely buy off the shelf cables, preferring to make my own.

It should work with 1/8" connector supplied with the DP-1. Polarity is where you are going to run into problems. If possible check the polarity (tip positive?) of the original adapter with a Multimeter and make sure it matches the one from the DP-1.
Nice scores. Also nice Ampeg RR, I have a '63.
Nice score. I've been interested in the Big Payback for a while now. Didn't know about the Slow Gear feature. Hmmmmm...
True, although I think the Brownface amps have cool trem too. I have a '59 2x10 Super (reverse panel) that uses four triodes (12AX7/7025) for tremolo.

Different brands of current generation tubes will obviously sound different. We prefer the sound and quality of JJ's and build around their specs.
In vintage amps I spend my money on NOS rectifier tubes and vintage speakers. That's where Ossie and I think the the magic is ;)
Nice!! I toured with a '65 Vibrolux (2x10) for years and loved it. My modded Princeton has a 12 in it, but I love 10's as well. Those Vibroverb reissues are cool.

I have always been a 'maker' since I was a kid, from skateboards to art to furniture. So when trying to transition from touring back to a semi-retired home life I thought about either building guitars or amps or pedals. I had already done pedalboards as a business in the 90's and early 2000's so I wanted to do something different.
My partner Ossie went to college for Electronics Engineering, a more specialized EE, but that was a while ago and may not be applicable to school these days. Most of the great amp builders I know started as repair guys and thats where their knowledge stems from. So if you are interested in amp building I'd suggest trying to apprentice under a skilled amp tech. Also building amp kits and modding amps from schematics on the internet can be helpful, but also dangerous as voltages inside most tube amps run 300+VDC and can kill you. I like learning from someone in person, who can tell me what to do and not do.
That's easy early 60's Blackface Deluxe Reverb. Although, we built me a modded Princeton Reverb recently that I've been playing a lot.

Both the guys in Linkin and Green Day are pretty nice guys. It's always cool to catch up with them when they come through town.
As far as local band gigs go, one of the main things when guitar teching is to try and make the gear as bullet proof as possible BEFORE the gig. Also, bring a spare guitar if possible, some spare cables, strings, picks, etc.

Yep, still answering questions. I'm gonna leave this AMA open for at least another day to try and answer as many as possible.
OK, to answer yours:
1. I've used Meguiars http://www.meguiars.com/ products over the years to remove scratches with some success. Since most guitars are painted with paint similar to cars. If you have a automotive paint store or high end detail place where you live, ask those guys what they might recommend, they are a wealth of knowledge usually.
2. I've never prepared a guitar specifically to withstand rain or sand. Most guitars are pretty good at combatting it on their own, and when rain has happened on an outdoor show, I've never had a guitar go down due to weather. I do make sure the guitars are dried off as much as possible before putting them away for the night. Repairs get done at the next show if needed, new pickups, output jack, etc. I have had to sweat-proof wireless packs over the years, as some guys will sweat so much the packs go out during the shows. Usually this means wrapping the pack in plastic wrap or putting it in a condom to keep it as dry as possible.
3. I haven't played a ton of the inexpensive stuff, but I did buy a J Mascis Squier Jazzmaster last year and it is one of the better playing guitars I've come across and I have left it completely stock. In fact it has been my main guitar lately and I have plenty of vintage and higher-end guitars. Over the years I have played a few of the LTD, Epiphone, etc. offering and usually find them to be pretty good as well. YMMV and if you have access to a large guitar shop, play as many models/manufacturers as you can and find what fits your playing and budget.
4. I can't really say specifically how the Korean manufacturers are doing. My JM was made in China I believe and the neck is perfect.

Nope. One thing I pride myself on is honesty, if I break something I tell the artist and it gets fixed or replaced. Last thing you want is something to go wrong in front of thousands of people that could have been prevented by owning up to it.

True.
The name came from our love of the vintage Orange amps that we were listening to while developing that model.
Usually neither, more like a smoothie in the morning. But, I do like a banana pancake.
For me I'd say Overdrive/Distortion/Boost, Chorus, Delay.
Doubt we would ever do it. Not our forte.
I always look/feel the neck, that is number one for me. It has to play well or no amount of tweaking of pickups, etc. will help it.

Session work is tough, it's not what you know but who you know.
As far as tech jobs, you basically just have to work your way up the ladder. Find a smaller band, start touring with them then make contacts with bigger acts and try to get hired on. There is no shortcut.
An English lighting guy once told me "It's the hardest job to get into , but it's even harder to get out of". Very true as guitar tech skills don't really translate to work at home unless you want to be a luthier or repair man.

I worked in a couple of music stores and also was in a regional touring band myself, that morphed into teching for some friends bands. Some of those bands got signed to major labels in the early 90's, so we all jumped in a van and toured the US and eventually Europe.
I had a couple of friends who were roadies (techs) for bigger bands such as Pearl Jam and Rage Against the Machine, and eventually my name got given to some production manager and I got a call and ended up on my first tour bus. From there, since this business is all word of mouth, you work for the opening band, meet the guys in the headliner's crew, do a good job, make contacts, get a call from one of those contacts for another gig, rinse, repeat ;)
I was actually semi-retired when I got called for Aerosmith in 2002. I turned it down, then called my wife , she said "Call them back"...
I have two that I go between, a Sock Monkey and The Orangutan.
Nope, but I am distantly related to Stan Laurel (Laurel and Hardy).
Maybe try some of the coated strings. More expensive, but might save money in the long run (less string changes). Good luck.
A good rule of thumb is to try an plug every piece of your rig into the same outlet via a power strip, etc. That will keep the ground loops to a minimum.

Hi. At some point probably, but these tube guitar amps have been around for 60+ years and most are still going strong. I'm sure software will have it's place especially with younger more tech savvy players and I'm not against it. But for a guitar player there is nothing like standing in front of a cranked amp, nothing.

60 cycle hum or a ground loop usually has nothing to do with the actually power supply/distibution, but with signal grounds. I use a transformer (like an Ebtech Hum Eliminator) to isolate those signal grounds, I never lift the AC ground on one of the amps to do this, this can be dangerous and risk a nice shock.
Assembling a noiseless signal path has a lot of factors, but using quality signal cables is a good start. If using a lot of pedals then an isolated power supply is also a good idea. Something people seem to forget that there are a lot of solder joints between your guitar and your speaker, each one of those connections can add noise.
As an aside to your question, if you do have a noise or ground loop problem troubleshoot it from one end to the other to find the culprit. Start with Guitar into amp, then guitar into pedal 1 into amp, then guitar into pedal 1 into pedal 2 into amps, etc. Don't just start unplugging things randomly and expect to find the problem (not saying you do this, but I've seen it done).
Sure, they did it in a few in the 60's and 70's.

Also, artists rarely break strings, but it happens. In 9mos with AC/DC I only had one string break, and that was the first gig, and before I saw how hard Stevie hit the guitar. I looked for burrs in the saddles (and changed a few over the course of the tour) every time I changed strings. So don't be afraid, and have a backup if possible.

Good question. My rule of thumb is I change strings when they need changing. What I mean by that is most guitars don't need new strings every gig, new strings are usually a little too bright for my tastes and sound better the second gig after being played a few songs. Every artist is different though, if someone has really corrosive sweat then they have to change strings more often. I normally change an artists 'main' guitar every gig and a backup (or backups) every few gigs depending on how much it is played. Also, when I change strings I look at the bridge and the nut carefully for burrs and sand those down and use something like Big Bends Nut Sauce on both saddle and nut.
Most guitars never need a refret unless the artist uses one guitar all night with large strings. Again, I go by a "when it needs it" philosophy and also "if it ain't broke, don't break it". No need to replace change something because you 'think' it's time. This goes for tubes as well, if your amp sounds great, don't re-tube.
Sure thing.

I haven't found too many two channel amps that I though both channels sounded great. There is almost always a compromise. One channel is great, the other, so-so.
So for me it's a one-channel amp with pedals (I love pedals) or sometimes two one-channel amps on at the same time in stereo.

Not really. A lot of those overly complex rigs are built by the techs trying to make it so no one can run it so they have 'job security'. This never works out as everyone is replaceable.
My Green Day rig for Jason White was a complicated rig built by me due to the fact there was no other choice (I ran all his effects except Wah and Volume from offstage). Here's what was going on, the Green Day guys use three distinct electric sounds, 1. Clean, 2. Mid (somewhat lo-fi), and 3. Big (full on Marshall). Also with Jason we had an acoustic bridge on his 335's to do all the acoustic parts directly into a DI (down a TRS cable). So the problem was that we needed to go from Acoustic to Electric (any of the 3 sounds) and back in an instant. Originally in 2005 I had a sort of double A/B box that turned on the Acoustic while muting the electric or turned on the electric while muting the acoustic (all while keeping the signal paths separate so that the Acoustic could never run through the amps *major feedback*). In 2009 I rebuilt the rig using an RJM loop switcher and some Custom Audio Electronics stuff to do all the switching via MIDI foot control.

You hit the nail on the head, probably the weakest link in a rig is the instrument jack. It get's a lot of wear, I don't change a ton of them, but when one starts acting up, you better change it before it goes dead in the middle of a show.
Wireless is great and the only way to go in a large scale venue, arena or stadium, etc. Unless the artist rarely moves (singer for instance). For smaller gigs I prefer the sound of a cable as long as no one is tripping over it constantly.
Actually our branded speakers are made by WGS. We do use Celestion's on occasion in some of our models.

Modelling amps aren't going away and in some cases make great sense for the player. Like a lot of touring guys using Kempers so they can fly anywhere, rent a Kemper, dump in their sounds and go!
I'm an old guy (52 yrs old) so I grew up on tube amps and I prefer them, there is this 'Nth' quality to tube sound that I really dig. 'Nth' meaning this unidentifiable 'thing' that tubes have.

Always, I mean never...
Seriously, my one golden rule is if I come into a gig and the rig is already built or partially built, I will go over every connector and remake any I deem not worthy. In effect, I don't ever want to have to say to an artist that whatever failed was somebody else's fault ("Hey, I DIDN'T build that cable")
That said, I don't just go into a gig and rip everything out and start over just to spend the band's money (a very common occurrence).
Also, I have used soldered and solderless cables and have had equal failure with both. I've also used just about every manufacturers connectors, some I like, some I don't.

To add to that, I always tell an artist, and I don't care who it is or how big their rig is, I will plug the guitar straight into the amp if that's the only way to make sound in front of the crowd. I'll then work on fixing the problem or subbing in a backup rig, but not take the whole show down.

Luckily they have been few and far between. Live TV is the worst though for little gremlins and such. When I did Live 8 in Berlin with Green Day, they couldn't get the acoustic DI line to work on Jason White's guitar for 'Blvd of Broken Dreams' (a pretty big deal). I took a Boss Acoustic Simulator pedal and put it in-line to fake the Acoustic signal, my guitar player (Jason) couldn't hear it in his monitors, but at least it was there for the TV broadcast...

Well, there have been a lot of guitars over the years (too many to count). But playing and working on Malcolm Young's early 60's Gretsch guitars (last year when I worked for Stevie Young) was probably the coolest most iconic guitars I've held on to. And Brad Whitford has some nice vintage stuff too, 'bursts, Strats, Teles, SG's, etc.

I've been lucky that almost everyone I've worked for has been cool and most have been great players. I must say working with the Black Crowes backing Jimmy Page in 2000 was definitely one of the coolest. Jimmy was such a great person to be around and he loves playing music.
Working on the Experience Hendrix tour, I must say I was surrounded by great players, Eric Gales, Eric Johnson, Dweezil Zappa, Vernon Reid, etc.
Yep, it happens. Wonder how often it happens to him? ;)

Almost every model we have produced is it's own design, not a copy of this circuit or that circuit. We mostly try to shoot for a certain 'sound' we have in our heads. Our first amp The Orangutan was aimed at nailing the guitar sounds we heard on 70's records like Humble Pie, Aerosmith, ZZ Top, etc.
All of our standard amp models are available on our website, and we do a lot of Custom stuff too. We build to order, so we don't have a shelf full of completed amps, every one is built from the ground up after the order is placed.

Brad is a great friend and boss. Yes, his role in 3 Monkeys is more of a promotional one, but he has great ideas and input on stuff just like Ossie and I do.
I was actually gonna start an amp business on my own when Ossie, who founded Blockhead Amps, said he's like to start a new company with me, which was great, he's already been doing it 10+ years. Anyway, we were having dinner with Brad, mentioned the amp company to him and he said "I want in on that". So we made him a partner.

WRITING.TITLE: [AMA] Greg Howard from 3 Monkeys Amps here to answer your questions! Ask Me Manything
WRITING.TEXT:
Hello redditors!! Im Greg Howard a 20+ year veteran touring guitar tech who has worked for a few cool bands over the years. Worked with Brad Whitford of Aerosmith off and on since 2002, worked for AC/DC in 2016, also Green Day, Daryl Hall and John Oates, Linking Park, Steely Dan, Jimmy Page The Black Crowes, The Verve Pipe, Cry of Love, along with many others.
In 2007 I started 3 Monkeys Amps with my partners Ossie Ahsen and Brad Whitford https://www.3monkeysamps.com recently we invented a solderless cable system for DC power cables called DC Solderless.
Glad to answer any and all questions about touring, guitar teching, rig building, amps, guitar setups, pedals, pedalboards, our DC Solderless cables, etc.
So AMA!!!
Recipe? Looks delicious.
Yup, that's where Fender got the idea. I've been using the Grolsch ones for 20+ years. I don't drink anymore, so easier to buy the Fender ones now ;)

Hey, it happens, especially on Les Pauls, as the angle of the strap is pretty severe. Looks like you'll need to replace the whole switch as from your pic it looks like a couple of the threads sheared off. Take it to a qualified repair shop (or Sam Ash or Gtr Center, if that's all there is). Shouldn't be too expensive. If it is and the switch still works, then put it off till you save up the $$. Won't hurt anything.
I'd advise getting some straplocks as well (I'm a touring gtr tech and I use them on all artist's guitars I work with, as it happens to the 'big' boys too). I like these for Les Pauls, as they are relatively cheap and work well without having to remove the original strap button. https://www.sweetwater.com/store/detail/099-0819-000?adpos=1o1 creative=55397627521 device=c matchtype= network=g product_id=099-0819-000 gclid=CIy11On-qNMCFRuBswodoNkOFQ
And, don't be discouraged, keep on playing, we all started out the same way.
Looks like he sheared off a couple of threads, so that plastic tip would not screw back on. Gonna need to replace the whole switch.

Ours doesn't use the standard side screw method, which is the only place I've seen the oxidation on solderless cables. I still use a George L's cable that I've had for close to 30 years in my touring set-up for tuning guitars, it's been all over the world, no oxidation, no problems.

Not sure which model you are referring to, but I don't think any of ours has a tranny right next to the input (maybe you are referring to the choke?). Anyway, Ossie the designer uses an electronic stethoscope to position the transformers on the chassis where they are quietest. Our amps are some of the quietest at idle I've ever heard (or not heard). Thanks for checking them out.
Yep, he loves them and has built many. Just no more room in the house...
He's old skool, no cell, no camera, no email. I did get him an iPad to watch YouTube on, he loves watching you guessed it, woodworking videos.
Thanks guys. He's great at it, unfortunately no more room in the house for big stuff like this. He is working on some bowl turning now.
Yep, for some reason it had trouble submitting. will re-submit. Thanks.

Went to visit my parents yesterday (an hour away) and my Dad showed me this Walnut Secretary he's almost finished with (he has some interior drawers to go. I thought this was an interesting design with the peaks in the doors (he said it was tough), I also like the curly walnut on the drawer fronts.
FYI My Dad was a mechanical engineer and has been making furniture (mostly Shaker) as a hobby for at least 40 years, he's in his 80's. He mostly uses his ancient Craftsman Table Saw (not even a cabinet saw) and a Craftsman Radial Arm Saw.
Thanks for checking this out. He taught me a bit, I'll post some of my stuff later.
Cool!! I'm excited. Have a good weekend. Greg
That would be Hans, Billie's tech since 2005. I teched for Jason White on the American Idiot and 21st Century tours.
Thanks for the order, we'll get the sample pack out tomorrow.
By Summer hopefully.
Sorry depth. Diameter is the same at .4"
It's a dual combination Fuzz and Overdrive. Johnny is doing some cool stuff over at Daredevil for sure.
Ah, yeah, shipping would be killer from W. Canada. :(
Thanks! They are at least .10" (2.5mm) smaller than the same GH made plugs (Disaster Area, etc.). Price will hopefully be in line with those plugs as they will be made in the USA.
Oh man, those are great. When I tech for Brad Whitford he uses one and loves it.
What is that Strat? Nice wear on it!!
Thanks, I'll check it out.
I appreciate that. Always glad to contribute.

Ha. I used the search (duh) and found it right after I hit reply. Great looking 'board, would you mind if I share on our Instagram/Facebook? Hit me with a PM with your Insta/FB credentials (if you have them) so I can tag you. Also, that is a killer pickguard on that Tele!!
Awesome, we appreciate the support. Can you point me to your post?

I've had as many soldered cables as solderless fail on me in 20+ years of touring. I actually have a George L's cable in my touring workbox that I use with my tuner(s) that is 30 years old and has never failed. But, I know a lot of people who will never use solderless and that's OK, to each his own.
Pretty easy to DIY if you are a bit handy. Get the tolex and glue from Mojotone build up a pedalboard frame and wrap it. ;)
Thanks. All the cords, both DC and the 1/4" audio are designed and made by my company 3 Monkeys Amps. The audio plugs are prototypes of our solderless 1/4" right angle audio connector.
Those are prototypes of our solderless 1/4" right angle audio connector. They work great and are really small.
We are always coming up with new ideas, so probably at some point. We got these small enough to use in most situations and the cable will bend at 90 degrees so it will work for most people.
Well, not all that useful except to make weird sounds. I wouldn't use it live unless it was for a certain effect and probably no more than a few seconds. It's fun to play around with though.
Well, that's part of it's charm. We have been adding a Master Volume as an option lately. Get in touch, we could mod yours with one.

Pretty sure I used this one https://www.lowes.com/pd/Rubbermaid-Laminate-0-625-in-D-x-23-8-in-L-x-11-8-in-W-White-Shelf-Board/4264327
Honestly, I was just walking around in the store and saw these and bought the smallest one. Comes in black too.
Yes, Nylon Cable Ties like these https://www.lowes.com/pd/Utilitech-10-Pack-1-in-Nylon-Cable-Ties/50005766

The Little Dual is what I used as the SGoS wasn't being made back then. And if you don't need the bells and whistles it would be fine.
I'd love to do an AMA, that sounds like fun.
That's me. I've used the Lehle Dual (and many other Lehle products) with no issues on touring rigs. I used one on Brad Whitford's rig for an entire tour.
Only black cable currently. I'm sure we'll do some colors eventually.

Bottom looks just like the top, but with small rubber feet, including one in the middle. Why would it need structure support? No way it's going to snap unless maybe you ran it over. I've been building these type boards for 25 years, never snapped one.
We are planning to do one soon. I will post a link here when we do. Thanks.
You can always add an Ojai to the Zuma.
I've used and liked the MXR/CAE MC403 20 outlets, couple of 18V, lots of mA. Designed by a guy that knows his stuff. I've seen them on Reverb for about $150, so not too pricey.
Nice work. How's that Robot?
Tell my wife that. Haha.
Thanks. Some people don't 'get' the amp look, but we didn't want to build another amp in a Marshall box, although I love the look of a vintage Marshall 50 watt head and cab.

Appreciate that. I've been building 'boards for at least 25 years. Even had a couple of pedalboard companies in the mid-90's/early 2000's. I always have a design or two sketched out at any time. I think I may have a problem...
Pretty fun, for the price it's a cool synth pedal. I need to get my hands on a Boss SY-300 and see how it compares to my old Roland GR-300. Hmmmm...
OK, cool. The plugs are pretty small (less than 1/2"), but if someone was really smashing the pedals close together, might run into a problem. I can never get mine too close, guess I have big feet ;)
Not to be spammy, but I invented them in 2015 and sell them through my amp company 3 Monkeys. Find them at www.dcsolderless.com Be glad to send you a sample to check out.

Built this up to mainly test out the Dirty Robot and Chicago Way. Signal chain is: TC polytune --Daredevil Custom The Chicago Way --BJFE Sea Blue EQ --Digitech Dirty Robot --MXR carbon copy.
I built the board from a Rubbermade shelf from Lowe's and some U-channel and handles I had lying around. Quick and easy, thinking of doing a video how-to on this style board with parts from Lowe's or Home Depot.
Anyway, thanks for checking it out. I don't get to read this subreddit often enough... G
